update.description: Based on the initial work of @scpeters and some discussion with the ROS team, this is a rough design document outlining how we should change SDF to support generic `<param>` elements. It is motivated by the current process of adding new parameters to the physics engines, which is a time-consuming process that might not be scalable.

content.raw:
Using both sounds reasonable. How does this policy sound:

1. Use an implicit parameters for development, testing, research, etc.
1. Migrate implicit parameters, with proper deprecation period, when parameter is deemed stable.

If folks like this approach, can this doc be updated with:

1. A plan to document implicit parameters.
1. A plan to write a tutorial on implicit parameters, and how they can be made explicit.
content.html:
Using both sounds reasonable. How does this policy sound:

  1. Use an implicit parameters for development, testing, research, etc.
  2. Migrate implicit parameters, with proper deprecation period, when parameter is deemed stable.

If folks like this approach, can this doc be updated with:

  1. A plan to document implicit parameters.
  2. A plan to write a tutorial on implicit parameters, and how they can be made explicit.

pull_request.title: Generic physics parameters in Gazebo and SDF

pullrequest.title: Generic physics parameters in Gazebo and SDF

content.raw:
I'll start with some pros/cons, which we might all agree about:

Explicit parameters

* Pros: better documentation, type safety
* Cons: more effort to add new parameters, physics API changes bleed into downstream tools (`gz physics` for example)
* Ideal use case: parameters we expect to stick around

Implicit parameters

* Pros: very easy to add new parameters (just start using them)
* Cons: hard to document semantic meaning and type information
* Ideal use case: development, physics engine hacking

In order of gazebo to be a useful tool for physics engine developers, I think having access to some implicit parameters is essential, even if it's only for unreleased development and testing code. Thinking ahead to the Generic Physics API, there is no way that the explicit approach would capture all the desired parameters.

In summary, I think we should use both, perhaps strongly encouraging or requiring all of our pull requests / released code to use explicit parameters, while allowing implicit parameters for development and third party code.
content.html:
I'll start with some pros/cons, which we might all agree about:

Explicit parameters

  • Pros: better documentation, type safety
  • Cons: more effort to add new parameters, physics API changes bleed into downstream tools (gz physics for example)
  • Ideal use case: parameters we expect to stick around

Implicit parameters

  • Pros: very easy to add new parameters (just start using them)
  • Cons: hard to document semantic meaning and type information
  • Ideal use case: development, physics engine hacking

In order of gazebo to be a useful tool for physics engine developers, I think having access to some implicit parameters is essential, even if it's only for unreleased development and testing code. Thinking ahead to the Generic Physics API, there is no way that the explicit approach would capture all the desired parameters.

In summary, I think we should use both, perhaps strongly encouraging or requiring all of our pull requests / released code to use explicit parameters, while allowing implicit parameters for development and third party code.

content.raw:
The reference to my previous comment is a good example of the purpose behind design docs. The first pull request sparked a concern about scaling, and eventually lead to this design document. Better to explore options before implementation than to be stuck with a bad implementation. 

After seeing the key/value option and the explicit parameter option, I currently lean toward explicit parameters. Can those who are interested ( @hsu, @jacquelinekay, @scpeters ) voice an opinion in this thread?
content.html:
The reference to my previous comment is a good example of the purpose behind design docs. The first pull request sparked a concern about scaling, and eventually lead to this design document. Better to explore options before implementation than to be stuck with a bad implementation.

After seeing the key/value option and the explicit parameter option, I currently lean toward explicit parameters. Can those who are interested ( @hsu, @jacquelinekay, @scpeters ) voice an opinion in this thread?

pullrequest.title: Generic physics parameters in Gazebo and SDF

content.raw:
Currently ODE has a decent amount of physics parameters, but the other physics engines have many unimplemented parameters. This is actually a huge block to our benchmarking work right now.

A while back (before gazebo 3.0), @hsu tried adding some parameters to sdformat and protobuf, and you said, "[Having separate message for each physics engine will not scale. This is essentially spreading the physics api outside of the physics library into message passing, and the tools. I'm not sure we should do this.](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/999/clean-up-ode-code-pass-through-some/activity#comment-1482231)" We declined pull request 999 without merging it.

Ever since that comment, I have abstained from adding new physics parameters because I have been eagerly awaiting the implementation of this design. Maybe that is why it appears that parameters are "infrequently modified or removed", but I really want to add more.

If you don't like this approach, that's fine, but we need something.
content.html:
Currently ODE has a decent amount of physics parameters, but the other physics engines have many unimplemented parameters. This is actually a huge block to our benchmarking work right now.

A while back (before gazebo 3.0), @hsu tried adding some parameters to sdformat and protobuf, and you said, "Having separate message for each physics engine will not scale. This is essentially spreading the physics api outside of the physics library into message passing, and the tools. I'm not sure we should do this." We declined pull request 999 without merging it.

Ever since that comment, I have abstained from adding new physics parameters because I have been eagerly awaiting the implementation of this design. Maybe that is why it appears that parameters are "infrequently modified or removed", but I really want to add more.

If you don't like this approach, that's fine, but we need something.

pull_request.title: Generic physics parameters in Gazebo and SDF

pullrequest.title: Generic physics parameters in Gazebo and SDF

content.raw:
My primary concern is that key/value pairs are hard to document and implement well. 

With the current implementation every parameter is explicit, which means they show up in [sdf](http://sdformat.org/spec), and [msgs](http://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/gazebo/msg-api/dev/classes.html). Key value pairs can be documented, but it will require more diligence.

Relying on key/value pairs for parameters has system introspection issues. The SDF library will no longer be able to check if a particular SDF file is valid based on the XML alone. You'd have run an SDF file through a program, such as Gazebo, and hope that an appropriate error message is generated when an unused parameter is encountered. Such an error message is difficult to generate, because Gazebo may not need the parameter but some other application may. 

Adding new parameters does not necessarily break ABI/API. It is safe to add a new parameter to SDF, and release a new minor version. It is also safe to add a new parameter to protobuf messages, as long as you follow a [few rules](https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/proto#updating). 

That leaves changing and removing parameters, which would break ABI/API compatibility. 

The scalabilty arguments are valid, but I'm not 100% convinced that this is a good idea. Especially since parameters are infrequently modified or removed.
content.html:
My primary concern is that key/value pairs are hard to document and implement well.

With the current implementation every parameter is explicit, which means they show up in sdf, and msgs. Key value pairs can be documented, but it will require more diligence.

Relying on key/value pairs for parameters has system introspection issues. The SDF library will no longer be able to check if a particular SDF file is valid based on the XML alone. You'd have run an SDF file through a program, such as Gazebo, and hope that an appropriate error message is generated when an unused parameter is encountered. Such an error message is difficult to generate, because Gazebo may not need the parameter but some other application may.

Adding new parameters does not necessarily break ABI/API. It is safe to add a new parameter to SDF, and release a new minor version. It is also safe to add a new parameter to protobuf messages, as long as you follow a few rules.

That leaves changing and removing parameters, which would break ABI/API compatibility.

The scalabilty arguments are valid, but I'm not 100% convinced that this is a good idea. Especially since parameters are infrequently modified or removed.

pullrequest.title: Generic physics parameters in Gazebo and SDF

content.raw:
Summarizing from an in-person conversation: allowing repeated elements (ie. arrays of primitive types) is tempting to me because it is easy to implement in protobuf, but it's tricky to represent it in sdformat. The following would work, but requires an extra element definition:
~~~
    <param name="points">
      <value type="vector2d">0 0</value>
      <value type="vector2d">0 1</value>
      <value type="vector2d">1 1</value>
    </param>
~~~
or
~~~
    <param name="points">
      <vector2d>0 0</vector2d>
      <vector2d>0 1</vector2d>
      <vector2d>1 1</vector2d>
    </param>
~~~

Maybe this is also difficult on the C++ side too? You would have to `Get<std::vector<Vector2d>>("points")`? That seems like a lot of extra parsing work.
content.html:
Summarizing from an in-person conversation: allowing repeated elements (ie. arrays of primitive types) is tempting to me because it is easy to implement in protobuf, but it's tricky to represent it in sdformat. The following would work, but requires an extra element definition:

    <param name="points">
      <value type="vector2d">0 0</value>
      <value type="vector2d">0 1</value>
      <value type="vector2d">1 1</value>
    </param>

or

    <param name="points">
      <vector2d>0 0</vector2d>
      <vector2d>0 1</vector2d>
      <vector2d>1 1</vector2d>
    </param>

Maybe this is also difficult on the C++ side too? You would have to Get<std::vector<Vector2d>>("points")? That seems like a lot of extra parsing work.

content.raw:
What about points in a polyline? Those are implemented with repeating `<point>` elements:

* [Gazebo example worlds/polyline.world](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/93ef26c232069fb784e7c464d87d136a64e09f19/worlds/polyline.world?at=default#cl-30)
* [sdformat spec for polyline_shape.sdf](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/fdd9fa972ff7e64240a0397020a2640a562049eb/sdf/1.5/polyline_shape.sdf?at=default): note that `required="+"` means it's allowed to repeat
content.html:
What about points in a polyline? Those are implemented with repeating <point> elements:

  • Gazebo example worlds/polyline.world
  • sdformat spec for polyline_shape.sdf: note that required="+" means it's allowed to repeat

content.html:
I think the best practice is:

template<typename T> bool ConvertParam(const msgs::Param &_msg, T _value);

// Call "bool ConvertParam(...)" and throw an exception if returns false
template<typename T> msgs::Param ConvertParam(const std::String &_key, const T &_value);

and the same pairs of functions for ConvertParamSDF.

This allows for a more convenient accessor function that still alerts the user in case of errors. If we like this idea, we could consider adding a similar scheme for G/SetParam in the physics engines and Joint functions.

pullrequest.title: Generic physics parameters in Gazebo and SDF

content.raw:
Oh, good to know.

If I'm reading this right, I was mistaken originally about protobuf versions packaged for ubuntu:

* [trusty: 2.5.0](http://packages.ubuntu.com/trusty/libdevel/libprotobuf-dev)
* [utopic: 2.5.0](http://packages.ubuntu.com/utopic/libdevel/libprotobuf-dev)
* [vivd: 2.6.1](http://packages.ubuntu.com/vivid/libdevel/libprotobuf-dev)

2.6.1 is available from a PPA in trusty, of course. But I have a feeling the protobuf team does not plan on releasing official debs for 2.6.1 in trusty or utopic. 

I'm not sure what to do about versioning. The implementation would be a lot cleaner if I could use these newer protobuf features right away in Gazebo 6. But then to install Gazebo in trusty and utopic, the user has to install a custom protobuf 2.6 library (something that we package or we give them through the PPA). Could that have cross-compatibility issues with other applications?

I also don't know how to implement this in a way that's cross compatible with Protobuf 2.5 and 2.6. You can't `#ifdef PROTOBUF_2.6` in a protobuf message declaration...
content.html:
Oh, good to know.

If I'm reading this right, I was mistaken originally about protobuf versions packaged for ubuntu:

  • trusty: 2.5.0
  • utopic: 2.5.0
  • vivd: 2.6.1

2.6.1 is available from a PPA in trusty, of course. But I have a feeling the protobuf team does not plan on releasing official debs for 2.6.1 in trusty or utopic.

I'm not sure what to do about versioning. The implementation would be a lot cleaner if I could use these newer protobuf features right away in Gazebo 6. But then to install Gazebo in trusty and utopic, the user has to install a custom protobuf 2.6 library (something that we package or we give them through the PPA). Could that have cross-compatibility issues with other applications?

I also don't know how to implement this in a way that's cross compatible with Protobuf 2.5 and 2.6. You can't #ifdef PROTOBUF_2.6 in a protobuf message declaration...
